entry.et: Middle English muche large, much, from michel, muchel, from Old English micel, mycel; akin to Old High German mihhil great, large, Latin magnus, Greek megas, Sanskrit mahat

def.dt: :great in quantity, amount, extent, or degree there is much truth in what you say taken too much time
:great in importance or significance nothing much happened
:many in number
:more than is expected or acceptable :more than enough the large pizza is a bit much for one person
:wonderful exciting
:terrible awful
:to a great degree or extent :considerably much happier
:very much gratified
:frequently often
:by or for a long time didn't get to work much before noon
:by far was much the brightest student
:nearly approximately looks much the way his father did
:the same in quantity not quite as much money
:to the same degree
:a great quantity, amount, extent, or degree gave away much
:something considerable or impressive
:however much :even though
:not to mention used especially in negative contexts to add to one item another denoting something less likely had trouble paying for a car, much less a high-definition TV
:by the amount indicated or suggested if they lose their way, so much the better for us
:something (as an amount or price) unspecified or undetermined charge so much a mile
:all that can be or is to be said or done so much for the history of the case

dt.un: used as an intensive the house burned like so much paper sounded like so much nonsense

def.dt: :even 2d scowls if I so much as look at him
:the quality or state of being great in quantity, extent, or degree
:very much the same
